text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide the right to privacy and self-determination. The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives. According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights. For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association. The Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime. The Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure. The Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. And the Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. The Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination. And the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people. It's both fortunate and unfortunate that those rights have not been specified. Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities, such as racial and ethnic groups, need special protection under the Constitution, particularly to ensure that they have a right to privacy. They have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes. So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination? The answer is not because of any lack of cases. The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggled out of one Virginia case in 1976 by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons. In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away. Why? Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend, the Court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights. And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion, the Court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings. After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army. It has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance. Another possible reason for the Court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases is that the Court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan, fear they would be outvoted on the issue. And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision. If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the Court will be more liberal, it is doubtful they will be outvoted. They will live long enough. Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health. And if Reagan is re-elected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century. So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates, to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year, and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights, for better or for worse. So when a man named Robert Uplinger was arrested and charged under that statute, the end result in the court was, well, if it's perfectly lawful to engage in the act, why should it be illegal to ask somebody to engage in the act? And they struck down the solicitation. They struck down the solicitation statute also. This time, the district attorney in Buffalo appealed the decision or asked for a writ of cert to the U.S. Supreme Court, and the U.S. Supreme Court granted it. And the speculation was that the reason they granted it was that they had changed their mind about the Onofre case, and they really wanted to review the underlying issues of the sodomy legislation in New York. And in fact, that was an argument that was made in the petition by the DA. Now, some events happened since that petition was filed, and when the final brief was filed for the State of New York, the District Attorney of Buffalo, he did not argue that the sodomy statute needed to be reconsidered. And an interesting twist, too, was that the Attorney General of the State of New York, Robert Abrams, filed an amicus brief reporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals that the law was unconstitutional. So you had, in effect, the State's Attorney General and a city DA on opposite sides of the same issue. NGRA filed an amicus brief in the Supreme Court arguing that the petition was impromptu and granted, and that they would just throw the whole thing out without deciding it. And what we're hoping is that they are not going to read the underlying issues, but one thing, they're not properly before the court, there wasn't an issue in the lower court decision, and secondly, they were not adequately briefed because, as I said, it was not an issue. Oral arguments have already been presented in that case. We're expecting a decision on it later this spring. And depending on what happens in that case, it could have a significant impact on your litigation for a good number of years to come. Another area of litigation that's going on is in the area of security clearances. Security clearances are necessary for people, many people who work for the government or work for private industry that do contracts with the government, generally in the areas of energy and defense. And what security clearance means is that the government says that you are okay to look at classified information and feel that you're not going to default this information. There's different levels of security clearances. Gay people over the years have had a great deal of problems getting security clearances, and what we found is that the government's policy on this is somewhat inconsistent. They do not have an interagency plan or set of guidelines or criteria. Each agency decides on its own, and there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised. What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies a person can get a security clearance. Some agencies don't. So-called intelligence agencies, I call them the police agencies, the FBI, the CIA, the National Security Agency are hanging in there tough, and they will not grant security clearances to anybody that they know is gay. There's been some recent litigation against the CIA. There's one case that was filed more than a year ago in the District of Columbia District Court. It's before Judge Barrington Parker, and he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment in that case for more than a year now. There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles, the U.S. District Court down there, involving John Green, who was an engineer with a company known as TRW. He's worked for TRW, I believe, for 13 years, and he's never had any problems. The CIA, in fact, has never said that he leaked any information, that he had bulged any information, but basically what they said was that he was gay, and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay. And therefore might default to information. So that argument breaks down when the person says, I'm not subject to blackmail, I'm open about my sexuality. My family knows, my friends know, it's no big deal to me. I don't know why it's a big deal to you, but to the CIA it's still a big deal. And they can't, they just cannot understand why there might be some kind of, or might not be some kind of problem here. So that case is pending the U.S. District Court. The government just yesterday filed this brief, they filed a motion to dismiss. They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case based on sovereign immunity. They said the government did not consent to be sued in this case. And they also said that the judiciary would be infringing on the executive branch of government by getting involved in this matter. They said the CIA had absolute discretion to decide who gets the security clearance and who does not. So they will be responsible for filing that on March 2nd. I'll talk only about two more issues. One is, briefly, some First Amendment cases that we're involved in. We find that a number of gay community newspapers, like here in San Francisco we have the Bay Area Reporter, are being censored at a number of prisons around the country. And some of the prisoners who want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not being allowed to read these papers. So we're going to be involved in a suit probably, and we feel lucky, the Congressional Correctional Institute in Kentucky, and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison, and possibly one down in Texas as well. And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students. I went to, well, I went to several. Undergraduate schools. I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes. And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events. And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections. We wanted to put a banner that said, Gay Pride Week, and the administration wouldn't let us. So we filed an action against the university. We didn't win, but it was probably because we weren't adequately prepared, because we found out from sort of some of our sources post-administration that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year because they were probably in some pretty serious trouble. And so the next year, we made an application to put up the banner, and it went up without any problems. Now this same school, sitting in a city, that has an anti-discrimination ordinance, which I helped lobby for in 1971, last year, they allowed gay students to be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay. So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance, it's not going to be worth a whole lot, and it's not enforced. So there are continuing problems going on. We found that there's another school called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out two students because they allege they're gay. There's a private college in the suburbs of Chicago that once granted a bachelor's degree to a student who's completed all of his coursework and said this person's gay and he doesn't meet the criminal character requirements of our schools, and he can't handle his degree. We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville, the school has granted official university recognition to the student organization there, but they won't grant them any office space or any funding or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition. There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students to get recognition at their campus, and my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast involved the lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate into the law school. Gay student organizations. So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students as well as many other areas that are important. We can become complacent here in California. It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore. We have a lot of protections, and people to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed. They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community as sort of this old hat. But in most parts of the country, there's a lot of protection. There's still a lot of problems, and that's what National Gay Rights Advocates is all about. It's writing these new laws about diversity and inclusion. Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality if they have not reached any consent? Because that seems to be something in California that is sort of an issue and it's very difficult to consider. Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area. We have not taken on any cases involving that issue. I can't say we've been presented with any. What we do in determining what cases to take is we basically wait for people to come to us, which is not much of a problem. I get calls every day. If a day doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call, so I'm not concerned about some kind of discrimination or adverse action. But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet. What do you do to talk about this? You're talking about this in housing. When you say gender is a law that says two unrelated individuals cannot live together and this is often against gay couples. Is the status of the person, has anything been done about it? We haven't had any complaints in a long time about that kind of problem. That is a way of certainly discriminating against gay people without being so forthright as saying that we're not going to allow two gay people to live together. The history of that kind of legislation, I'm not so sure it was necessarily anti-gay, but it was intended to keep noise down and to protect sort of family-type environments. But it certainly didn't have an impact on gay people. Some areas like that, it's very subtle with the legislation. Some states like Virginia, it's very blatant. Thank you.

segments.text: The United States Constitution does not mention sexual freedom, but the United States Supreme Court, whose main job is to interpret the Constitution, has found that the Constitution does provide the right to privacy and self-determination.
The Court has not defined this right very clearly, but it does recognize the right to, for instance, an abortion within limits, and the right to use and receive information about contraceptives.
According to the Supreme Court, the basis for this right comes from the protections of the Bill of Rights.
For instance, the First Amendment's freedom of religion, freedom of speech, and freedom of association.
The Third Amendment's protection of each citizen's home from the quartering of soldiers in peacetime.
The Fourth Amendment's protection of each citizen's person and home against unreasonable search and seizure.
The Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
And the Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
The Ninth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination.
And the Ninth Amendment's protection from governmental infringement of certain unspecified rights of the people.
It's both fortunate and unfortunate that those rights have not been specified.
Besides finding this right to privacy, the Supreme Court has indicated that groups considered to be what they call discrete and insular minorities,
such as racial and ethnic groups, need special protection under the Constitution,
particularly to ensure that they have a right to privacy.
They have equal access to this nation's political and governmental processes.
So, with all these protections, why hasn't the Supreme Court upheld the rights of gays and lesbians to live and work without discrimination?
The answer is not because of any lack of cases.
The Court ducked a number of gay rights issues in the 1970s and wiggled out of one Virginia case in 1976
by affirming a lower court decision without hearing any arguments or giving any reasons.
In short, the Supreme Court has hoped the issue of gay rights would go away.
Why?
Well, because with all of these other holdings setting the trend,
the Court would appear extremely inconsistent if it decided against gay rights.
And yet, if it decided in favor of gay rights, despite negative public opinion,
the Court might undermine its authority and jeopardize its ability to enforce unpopular rulings.
After all, the United States Supreme Court has no army.
It has no army to back up its decisions, nor does it have control of federal funds with which to coerce compliance.
Another possible reason for the Court's reluctance to handle gay rights cases
is that the Court's two liberal members, Thurgood Marshall and William Brennan,
fear they would be outvoted on the issue.
And they've been delaying gay rights cases because they fear a bad decision would be worse than no decision.
If Brennan and Marshall are stalling for a time when the Court will be more liberal,
it is doubtful they will be outvoted.
They will live long enough.
Brennan is 77, Marshall is 75 and in poor health.
And if Reagan is re-elected, we probably will have an extremely conservative Supreme Court for the rest of this century.
So, tonight we have asked Leonard Graff, the legal director of National Gay Rights Advocates,
to tell us what cases are pending in the nation's courts, including the Supreme Court this year,
and what the chances are that 1984 will be a major year in the history of gay rights,
for better or for worse.
National Gay Rights Advocates, which is based in San Francisco,
is a private, non-profit law firm that acts as a clearinghouse for a large number of gay rights cases throughout the nation.
It is similar to the American Civil Liberties Union in that it fines lawyers nationwide
who are willing to donate their time to specific cases.
As legal director for the past year and a half, Leonard Graff coordinates those legal efforts.
They're all yours.
Thank you very much.
I'm pleased to be here tonight to talk to you about the current gay rights litigation that's going on around the country.
And what I'd like to do is sort of break it down by different categories.
And rather than lecture, I just assume make it more of a discussion.
So, if you have questions as I'm going along, feel free to raise your hands and interrupt.
I understand that a good number of you are not law students.
And so, I'll try.
I'll try to keep my terms as general and in the lay language as possible.
If you don't understand something I'm talking about, please let me know and I'll try to explain it the best I can.
I'd like to start out first talking about an area which is very important to gay rights advocates.
It's an issue we've been working on for about five years, and that's the immigration naturalization issue.
And what I'll probably do is conclude with an issue which I think many of you will find important,
which is the rights of gay students in this country.
And by no means is this issue settled at all.
In the area of immigration naturalization, we won at Gay Rights Advocates a very important victory
in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in the case of Carl Hill versus INS.
And the Immigration Nationality Act prohibits homosexuals from entering the country.
However, you don't find the word homosexual anywhere in the immigration nationality.
What you find is a Supreme Court decision which has interpreted the language of the act to exclude homosexuals.
And the precise terminology that they interpreted was psychopathic personality.
Since gay people are afflicted with a psychopathic personality, they must be excluded from the country.
Now the question is, which we raised in the Carl Hill case, is how do you determine who is a homosexual?
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
It is our position at Gay Rights Advocates to determine who is a homosexual.
Gay Rights Advocates said the only way to make this determination under the law is through an examination by a public health service doctor.
And that doctor must examine the arriving alien and say to that alien,
to our gay, issue what is known as a class A certificate, and then the INS can exclude the person from the country.
Now the government's position is that a person is able to decide for themselves whether or not they're gay.
And if they say they're gay, they are gay.
gay and can be excluded from the country. This is the issue. The U.S. District Court
here in the Northern District of California agreed with gay rights advocates that a doctor's
certificate from the Public Health Service must issue. The case involved Carl Hill, who
is a tourist, who is here for pleasure, and a journalist, a photographer for a London
newspaper. Now the same issue arose again in the case of Richard Longstaff, which is
a case that we have just filed a petition for review in the United States Supreme Court,
the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision. The Fifth Circuit sits in New Orleans. Mr.
Longstaff is a resident of Dallas, Texas. He's been here about 20 years now. He came
here on a valid immigrant visa. He subsequently opened up two boutiques, clothing stores,
and hairdressing salons. He employs about 20 citizens of this country. He pays over
$100,000 a month. He pays over $100,000 a month. He pays over $100,000 a month. He
pays over $100,000 a month. He pays over $100,000 a month. He pays over $100,000 a month. He
pays over $100,000 a month. He pays over $100,000 a year in income taxes. And our government
has said to Richard Longstaff, you're not good enough to be an American citizen. Why
has our government said that? Because Richard Longstaff is gay. And that is the position
that the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld. So what we have now is a clear conflict
between two circuits. I might have skipped over this. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
here has affirmed the decision of Carl Hill. What we did was file a petition in the Supreme
Supreme Court, asking them to review the Fifth Circuit decision and to resolve the conflict
between the two different courts and appeals. We feel that there's a good chance that the
Supreme Court will agree to hear the case. Part of the reason is that there's no constitutional
issues. We're not asking this court, this very conservative Supreme Court, to create
any new constitutional issues of rights for gay people. All we're asking them to do is
resolve what is essentially an inter-agency dispute, and it's more of a question of statutory
construction. So our petition was filed in that case at the end of January. The government's
brief is due on Friday, and the new case clerk at the Supreme Court tells me that the Supreme
Court will probably make a decision in three to four weeks after that. So we could be seeing
a decision in that soon. Here in the Ninth Circuit, the Supreme
Court filed a petition for what's known as a re-hearing on the bond, meaning that they
wanted the entire Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to review that decision, and
the Ninth Circuit refused to grant that petition. That came down January 17th. So what we'll
find, too, is that the government will undoubtedly be asking the Supreme Court to also review
the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I
think, to ask for that review is because they're going to be asking the Supreme Court to review
the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be inspired, I think,

is because they're going to be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the same issue in the Carl Hill case. Part of the reason that they'll be asking the Supreme Court to review the
that would eliminate the sexual deviance and psychopathic personality exclusions of gay people from the country.
The next area I want to talk to you about is the military.
The military has an absolute policy that gay people cannot serve,
and the only exception to this policy does not really afford the status of being gay,
but someone who commits a homosexual sexual act.
If they renounce that act, they say,
oh, Christ, was I drunk last night, I didn't know what I was doing,
you know, it was a mistake, it's never going to happen again,
please let me stay in the military, they can stay in.
Other than that, everybody else is out.
Now, the progress that we've made in the last few years, at least at the discharge,
will be under honorable conditions and will be entitled to full benefits.
However, for somebody who's chosen to make a career of the service,
this can still be pretty severe.
You've been in for so many years to lose all the benefits in your particular chosen career,
and to have the government, in effect, say to you,
well, you're not good enough to fight and die for your country either.
We have a test case pending in the Washington, D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals now,
involving a man who was originally stationed out here at Monterey Language Institute.
That's Jim Jonenberg.
He's a specialist in Korean cryptology.
He had been in the service for nine years.
Three months before his discharge, he had been given a $12,000 reenlistment bonus.
He had had accommodation after accommodation after accommodation.
They thought he was an excellent soldier until they found out he was gay.
They kicked him out.
The strategy of bringing the case in the District of Columbia
was that by reputation, the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals
is the most liberal in the country.
And in addition, the issue had been decided here in the Ninth Circuit
some years ago by a case that we had brought and lost,
and that's known as Beller v. Lindendorf.
So there was no avenue available for redress here.
And the strategy also would be that if we were able to get into the D.C. Court,
then that would resolve the issue for all soldiers,
because the issue of jurisdiction and venue revolved around
where was the defendant located.
It was our position in the Department of Defense
and the headquarters of the Department of Navy were located in Washington, D.C.
And the government fought us tooth and nail on this.
In fact, two-thirds of their brief, they argued that the court didn't have jurisdiction.
And essentially, for the merits of the case, all they did was say,
well, another court out there in San Francisco decides the issue,
and so it's really nothing but upset.
Well, we won half that case.
We won the jurisdiction issue.
We lost on the merits.
Now we're in the Court of Appeals, and our strategy, we found, backfired on us.
Because the odds maybe were 1,000 to 1 of drawing three conservative judges
and we drew three of the most conservative judges you could ever want to have.
One of them started asking questions about did the right to privacy
include the right to have sex with animals?
And you have to start off at this level.
You can't be too optimistic about the result.
One of the other judges, who was a Reagan appointee to the bench,
was a former professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School.
And a student who did work for gay rights advocates as a volunteer last summer
had this judge as a professor for constitutional law.
And when this man came to the issue of abortion rights,
he said, I'm Catholic, and I have nine children,
and that's enough said about abortion.
Let's move on.
So, as you can see,
I'm not too optimistic about any of that case.
There was a really great brief filed by the American Civil Liberties Union
in that amicus parotid brief, or friend of the court brief.
And what the ACLU did was to trace the rationale
that the military uses for excluding gays,
and they compared it to the same rationale
that the military used to segregate blacks from the service.
To say, look, white men are never going to sleep in the same barracks as black men.
A white soldier is never going to sleep with a black soldier.
A black soldier is never going to sleep with a black soldier.
And so they kind of maintained control and demand respect.
And this is the same kind of thing they say about gays and lesbians in the service,
that it just isn't going to work out.
And what they're doing is trying to institutionalize
some of these prejudices rather than trying to deal with the underlying problem.
So it's a very good and very detailed brief and very enlightening
and I hope the court takes some note of it.
The paradox to what's going on in the military is that
if you are a civilian employee of the military,
it's almost impossible to get rid of you,
regardless of what kind of activity you're involved in.
The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals has recently held that
a person who is a convicted child molester
still cannot be discharged from the Navy,
absent a showing that there was some connection
with his job duties in the Navy,
what we call the nexus between his activity
and his job requirements.
So in another area that we find the problem is that
people who want to make a career out of the military,
they make every effort to get rid of them as soon as they can.
And those who want to get out,
somebody discovers after they're in the service
that they realize that their sexual orientation
is not really what they thought it was,
and they come to their commanding officer and say,
I'm gay,
these people flounder around in the system,
often for a year or more before they're discharged,
even though the regulations are so man-made.
And how we resolve that problem,
I can't really say,
but it's really sort of a schizophrenic kind of attitude
where they just can't make up their mind what they want.
Other problems that we found now, too,
is that the military in some instances
are trying to prosecute soldiers
for asking for a discharge,
saying that they enlisted fraudulently,
that they knew at the time that they enlisted
that they were gay,
that they were gay,
that their enlistment therefore was fraudulent,
and they're trying to have them prosecuted.
There's a case up on appeal
in the Tenth Circuit Court in Denver,
and it's been there for some time,
so we should see a decision pretty soon in that case.
Another thing that we find the military is doing now
is suing people who've gone through ROTC,
and apparently they have some kind of program
where they subsidize their educational benefits,
and the case that came before us last year,
there was a person who went through medical school,
of course, in the U.S. Army,
and then when he finished said,
I'm sorry, I can't do my six-year stint
not because I look like I'm gay.
The Army said,
well, I think we're going to have to sue you
for $60,000 to reimburse us
for the cost of your education.
We were willing to defend this man,
but he didn't have the desire
to go through several years of litigation.
It takes a lot of fortitude to go through that,
and what he did instead was file a bankruptcy.
But in any case,
the military picked up the bill,
or for those of you who are working,
I guess we all picked up the bill in a sense,
which leads me to the next thing that we've done
is based on some data we've collected
over the last couple of years,
we can make a pretty good estimate
that the cost of separating people
from the military is at least $20 million a year,
that on average the military separates
about 1,800 soldiers a year from the service
because of homosexuality,
and that based on a recent RAND Corporation study,
the cost of training a soldier through basic training
the first 22 weeks is $100,000.
So a simple arithmetic will show
that that's $18 million,
and in my experience it's most of the people
that are being discharged
are being around for a lot more than $22 million.
What's the situation with conscription
where somebody turns 19
and is supposed to go to the post office
and says, I'm gay?
How does the system deal with that?
Well, you probably wouldn't necessarily
tell the postmaster,
but you would still have to register,
and it wouldn't really become an issue
until you were called up.
And at that time what happens is
that you're given a questionnaire
and asked you to list all of your childhood diseases
and broken bones,
and there's a list
and there's a square somewhere
that says how you're afflicted with homosexual tenderness.
What happens then though?
If you check the box and say you are so afflicted,
then you will be deferred.
You will not be taken or inducted into the military.
You cannot be inducted into the military.
If you do not check the box,
you could be inducted.
However, if you fraudulently,
if you know that you're gay,
you don't check that box,
you are subject to penalties,
you are subject to penalties
of as much as five years in prison
if they could subsequently prove the case against you.
Let's talk about deployment discrimination a little bit.
Something that's been in the news just recently
was AB1 finally passed both houses
and sitting on Duke's desk waiting for a signature.
What most people don't know in this state
is that all that bill,
all it does is codify a Supreme Court decision
which already extends sexual orientation,
discrimination protection
to all employers in the state.
The only thing is that not all employees are covered.
And this was the case of gay law students
for specific telephone and telegraph.
And I say it doesn't cover all employees
because it only covers those employees
who are open
or out on the job.
Their employer's got to know that they're gay.
Because part of what the Supreme Court of California
said in that case was
that being out on the job is political activity.
And that in this state,
an employer may not discriminate
against an employee based on political activity.
And political activity is much broader
than partisan politics.
It goes beyond the Democratic and Republican parties.
It includes political causes.
Women's rights, labor union rights,
gay rights.
So what the AB1 does is protect those people
who are not out on their job.
And it also gives them an administrative remedy
by going through the Fair Employment
and Housing Administration
rather than having to file a suit directly in court.
Other employment work that we're doing
at Gay Rights Advocates,
one involves a suit against an act
known as the Helms bill in Oklahoma.
The Helms bill is essentially similar
to the Briggs Initiative that was up here
in California a few years back.
Well, the Briggs Initiative was defeated
here in California.
It's law in Oklahoma.
And we filed a suit challenging that bill.
And we lost the district court level in Oklahoma.
We have that case now up in the Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit in Denver.
We had oral arguments last September,
so we're looking for a decision in October.
We're looking for a decision any time in that case.
The Helms bill involved,
the main issue was First Amendment
and freedom of expression.
That was the main cause of action.
There was also, we raised,
the due process and equal protection arguments
as well as the right to privacy.
And this kind of litigation,
I'll tell you, for some of you who are law students
and don't realize, and the rest of you are not,
we're often, quite frankly, flying by the seat
of our pants.
I mean, this is new.
And when we're in the courts and we're making new law,
the gay rights litigation that's going on in this country
is essentially taking place in the last 10 to 15 years.
Ten years ago, GRA didn't exist,
and there weren't no gay legal organizations
around the country.
And most of the states still had sodomy laws in the books,
and it's not uncommon to find all sorts of oppressive
legislation in the books.
We don't have a lot to look toward in terms of precedents.
We have to analogize a lot to the struggles that were won
in the women's movement and the black movement
and other First Amendment types of cases,
the privacy decisions that came out of the abortion litigation
and the contraceptive litigation.
That's where we sort of draw from.
Sometimes we make analogies,
sometimes we just make up new theories.
You have to go in there.
See, we feel, gay rights advocates,
we have a very aggressive litigation posture.
If we don't go into court and file suit,
then we've lost before we've even started.
There is, in a sense, nothing to lose
by going into court because,
in the case of the Helmsville situation,
the bill's on the books.
And if we lose, the bill's still on the books,
so what did we lose?
But at least we go in there and fight.
We have a chance of winning.
And in addition, we feel there's some other benefits.
There's educational benefits.
There's consciousness raising.
There's all the press we've got.
We've engendered a lot of good press.
People just cannot believe the situations
I've been ascribing to you tonight
about the military and immigration,
these kind of things happening in America today in 1984.
It's just incredible.
And so we feel there's a certain value
to bringing lawsuits, win or lose.
